title: Watching the Sun's Big Storm with Spacecraft
summary: The Sun spins slowly, so we can only see parts of it for two weeks at a time from Earth. A spacecraft called Solar Orbiter, launched by the European Space Agency in 2020, helps us see more. It orbits the Sun every six months and can look at areas we normally can't see, like the far side. In 2024, Solar Orbiter watched a very active solar region called NOAA 13664 for a long time. This region caused big geomagnetic storms on Earth, making beautiful auroras visible in places like Switzerland. Scientists combined data from Solar Orbiter and another spacecraft, NASA's Solar Dynamics Observatory, to study NOAA 13664 for 94 days without stopping. This is the longest continuous observation of a solar region ever, helping us learn how magnetic fields on the Sun create storms.

background_read: The Sun is a star that gives us light and heat. It has areas called active regions where storms happen. These storms can send energy to Earth, causing auroras and sometimes affecting technology. Scientists use spacecraft to study the Sun and learn how to predict these storms to keep us safe.
Article_Structure: WHO: Scientists like Ioannis Kontogiannis and Louise Harra, and spacecraft like Solar Orbiter and NASA's Solar Dynamics Observatory.
WHAT: They observed a big solar storm region called NOAA 13664 for 94 days using two spacecraft.
WHERE: The Sun, especially areas not visible from Earth, and effects seen on Earth like in Switzerland.
WHY: To understand how solar storms form and help predict them better.

perspectives.description: Scientists are excited because this is the longest continuous observation of a solar region, helping us learn more about the Sun.
